messageBody:
I've not found the JUnit "support" in any IDE useful for TDD. They
all assume that you are testing a class that already exists, and if it
does, they generate one test per method of that class, which produces
unhelpful test classes with unhelpfully named tests.

--Nat

2009/4/19 Karl Krasnowsky <karlkras@...>:
>
>
> This question is really targeted to those who have used Kent Beck's book,
> Test-Driven Development within the context of the NetBeans IDE, otherwise
> please disregard.
>
> Maybe someone here can provide a pointer to already available information on
> this.
> I'm using Kent Beck's book, Test-Driven Development as a tutorial and was
> looking at how i might use NetBeans with its JUnit plugin to mimic his
> recommended processes, but right out of the gate I'm having a fundamental
> issue.
> A standard practice of KB's method is to code the test before any code is
> written, and then backfill the empty bits (class, methods, variables, etc.)
> to make the test work.
> for example, here's the first JUnit test he shows in chapter 1 to begin
> building from:
> Code:
> public void testMultiplication() {
> Dollar five = new Dollar(5);
> five.times(2);
> assertEquals(10, five.amount);
> }
>
> Problem I'm having is, if I'm creating tests out of the context of the Java
> project, tests in NB aren't created until you have a class with runtime
> methods to create tests from. So I have a chicken egg sort of situation. NB
> would do the obvious thing, i.e., have tests generated from code, so the
> above doesn't make any sense as it implies that the code is generated from
> the test, which is a cool idea of the IDE could support it.
> I have experience using JUnit, so the framework itself isn't in question,
> but how to apply this methodology within the IDE format is.
> Do I have to simply short-circuit the default process that NB and the JUnit
> plugin manufacture?
>
> thanks in advance for any help on this,
> Karl
>
